answers: Kosovo AND Serbia [accept Republic of Kosovo or Republika e Kosovës for "Kosovo"; accept Republic of Serbia or Republika Srbija for "Serbia"]
Republic of North Macedonia [or Republika Severna Makedonija, or Republika e Maqedonisë së Veriut]
parts: Name these two countries led by Aleksandar Vučić ("VOO-chich") and Avdullah Hoti, respectively.
With their deal, Kosovo and Serbia sought to join a "Mini" version of this economic and political area of Europe, governed by a namesake treaty which abolishes passport and border controls within it.

This country, like Kosovo and Serbia, made joining the "Mini Schengen Zone" a key goal of economic development. This country added "North" to its name as part of a compromise with its neighbor Greece.

answers: Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland
parts: Give this executive title, whose holders were expected to consult with a Council of State of up to 21 members. The first holder of this title commanded the New Model Army along with Thomas Fairfax.
Oliver Cromwell took the title "Lord Protector" after his victory in this conflict, which resulted in the execution of the Stuart king Charles I.
This document, authored by John Lambert, officially invested Cromwell with the title of "Lord Protector". It also prevented Catholics and known Royalists from voting and worshipping freely.
Name this writer whose poems, such as "To a Mouse," are written in the Scots language.
In this Robert Burns poem, the title farmer ignores his wife's advice to not get drunk on Sunday, after which he sees a vision of "warlocks and witches in a dance".

The narrator of "Tam O'Shanter" calls this allegorical figure "inspiring" and says of him, "What dangers thou canst make us scorn!" Burns's "ballad" of this figure describes "three kings into the east" who swore this figure "should die".

answers: myoglobin [do not accept or prompt on "hemoglobin"]
phenylalanine AND tyrosine [accept Phe or F for phenylalanine; accept Tyr or Y for tyrosine; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Tea-colored urine may indicate this protein, which is released by skeletal muscle destruction and has a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve.
Urine that darkens under sunlight may indicate a group of diseases named for these compounds, which contain 4 pyrrole rings. One of them binds to iron in heme.

Urine that blackens when exposed to air may indicate alkaptonuria, a disease caused by inability to break down metabolites of these two amino acids. Along with tryptophan, these two amino acids allow quantification of protein concentration in the A280 method.

answers: Do The Right Thing (by Spike Lee)
parts: Carter borrowed from one of these artworks to design a gold-studded costume for What's Love Got to Do with It. David Fincher directed one of these works for Madonna's song "Vogue".
Carter asked local artist NaSha to paint a misspelled t-shirt reading "Bed-Stuy" for this film, for which she also designed Radio Raheem's iconic knuckle rings.

Carter unusually used this technique to design many of the costumes for Black Panther. The set of Gilles-Alexandre Deschaud's ("zheel-ah-lek-SOND deh-SHOW'Z") award-winning short film Chase Me was created entirely using this technique.

answers: omega cross omega cross r [It's technically omega cross (omega cross r), since the cross product isn't associative; omega cross omega is zero.]
parts: Name this fictitious force that appears along with the centrifugal and Euler forces when an object moves in a rotating reference frame.
When applied to the Earth, the strength of the Coriolis force is proportional to this function of the latitude.

The centrifugal force in a rotating reference frame equals negative mass times this function of the angular velocity vector, omega, and the radial position vector, r. Give an answer in terms of omega and r that uses at least one vector operation, and assume parentheses are implied.

answers: conch shell [or sacred conch; or divine conch; or shankha; or chank; accept vamavarta shankha or dakshinavarti shankha; accept Shankha Kshetra; prompt on seashell or snail shell]
om [or onkara; accept pranava, akshara, or ekashara]
milk [or kshira; or khir; or shir; or dugdha; or dudh]
parts: Name this instrument played in Hindu rituals. Vishnu holds one named Panchajanya ("pawn-chuh-JUN-yuh") in his upper-left hand, representing his control of sound and the universe's interconnectedness.
The conch's sound represents this sacred syllable, which embodies Atman and Brahman and so is commonly used in Hindu prayers.

Images of Vishnu are often bathed by pouring water or this liquid from a conch. The conch is one of the fourteen ratnas ("RUT-nuh'z") or treasures made from a large body of this liquid, which is also poured over lingas.

answers: Jamaica Kincaid [or Elaine Cynthia Potter Richardson]
At the Bottom of the River
parts: Name this author who wrote about a young woman growing up in the West Indies in her story "Girl". She wrote about a girl who becomes an au pair in her novel Lucy.
Kincaid included her story "Girl" in this collection, whose other stories include "In the Night". In its title story, a girl names objects like a flute made of wood in order to embrace her identity.
"In the Night" and "Girl" were published in this Manhattan-based magazine which also published James Thurber's "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty".

answers: Nordic Bronze Age [prompt on Bronze Age]
parts: Name this archaeological culture whose sites - such as the King's Grave - contain imported Mycenaean weapons, evidencing its extensive trade with the rest of Europe.
The most valued export of the Nordic Bronze Age was this brownish fossilized tree resin, prized for its use in jewelry.

Nordic Bronze Age sun worshippers created many of these works depicting their rituals. Derived from the Greek for "rock carving," this term denotes pictures made by removing a rock's surface, as done by the Anasazi.

Camille Pissarro created a series of 14 paintings depicting what Parisian street at various times of day and in different weather conditions? One of those paintings depicts a Mardi Gras parade on this street.
This contemporary of Pissarro used Nadar's apartment to paint the Boulevard des Capucines. This artist's painting Impression, Sunrise helped coin the name of the Impressionist movement.
A Pissarro painting depicts steam ships leaving this city's harbor on an "overcast day". Monet painted a series depicting this city's cathedral at various times of day.

answers: smallpox [accept Variola major or Variola minor]
parts: Name these indigenous people of the Caribbean who interacted with Christopher Columbus upon his arrival on Hispañola in 1492. Words from their language were adapted into the English words "tobacco" and "barbecue".
A 1518 epidemic of this "Old World" disease was responsible for the deaths of 90% of the Taíno population. Edward Jenner developed a vaccine for this disease.
Areytos were often composed to honor these Taíno deities, who were often represented as stone or wooden idols. One of them who governed storms, named Juracán, lends his name to the word "hurricane".

answers: Henry James [prompt on James] (The novel is Washington Square.)
parts: Many critics cite a novel about a raft trip down the Mississippi by this author from Hannibal, Missouri as the first Great American Novel.

This author introduced the abbreviation "GAN" for the Great American Novel. A park in Manhattan titles this author's novel about the heiress Catherine Sloper, who eventually rejects the gold-digging Morris Townsend.
This author of the Civil War novel Miss Ravenel's Conversion from Secession to Loyalty coined the term "Great American Novel" in an essay for The Nation magazine.

answers: passacaglia ("pah-suh-KAHL-yuh") [accept Passacaglia and Fugue in C minor]
parts: Name this composer of dozens of chorale ("koh-RAHL") preludes which heavily influenced those of J.S. Bach. His only works published in his lifetime were two sets of 7 trio sonatas.
Buxtehude's preludes and dozens of his other pieces were written for this loud keyboard instrument, as was Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D minor, which appears in Fantasia.
Buxtehude wrote a D minor organ piece in this form in 3/2 time. A C minor Bach organ piece pairs a section in this form with a fugue and consists of 20 variations on a ground bass ostinato.
Identify these samples which scientists at Vostok and McMurdo stations obtain via drilling.
Excavating ice cores is one of our sources on the history of this landmass, which contains the world's largest polar desert.

Findings of this substance in ice cores indicate that Antarctica was home to large forests about 15 to 20 million years ago. This "epicuticular" substance consists of a mixture of n-alkanes, making it strongly hydrophobic.

answers: atheists [or atheism] (Wolmar is a portrayal of the Baron d'Holbach.)
parts: Name this epistolary novel whose title character is a "New Héloïse" who is taught by Saint-Preux ("sont-proo").
Julie is by this French philosopher and author who described an ideal education in the novel Emile ("eh-MEEL").

In Julie, Rousseau portrays one of his French-German philosopher contemporaries as Wolmar, a "virtuous" example of these people. The Savoyard Vicar from Emile has the "manners of a beggar" and principles of one of these people, and "affects to be" one to be a contrarian.

answers: King Lot [or Loth; or Lothus; or Leudonus; or Lewdwn; or Llewdwn Lluydauc; prompt on Lleu; prompt on Lothian, Laudonia, Leudonia, Lodonesia, Lowden, Loudan, or Lodainn]
Sir Gawain [or Gauwaine; or Gwalchmei ap Gwyar; or Walwen; or Gualguanus; or Waluanus; or Gauvain; accept Sir Gawain and the Green Knight]
Geoffrey of Monmouth [or Galfridus Monemutensis, or Galfridus Arturus, or Galfridus Artur, or Gruffudd ap Arthur, or Sieffre o Fynwy]
parts: Name this legendary king of the Picts who, in the post-Vulgate Cycle, is slain by King Pellinore, resulting in a blood feud between the two men's families.
The feud against Pellinore is carried on by this son of Lot, a Knight of the Round Table. In another story, this man fights the Green Knight.

The History of the Kings of Britain written by this clergyman from Monmouth ("MAWN-muth") elevates Lot to a more prominent role than earlier tales, making him a close ally of Arthur and heir to the throne of Norway.

answers: psychophysics [or perceptual physics; prompt on psychometrics]
just-noticeable difference [or JND; prompt on noticeable difference]
parts: Name this field pioneered by Gustav Fechner which quantitatively investigates the relationships between stimuli and resulting sensations.
Psychophysics often searches for this value, defined as a change in stimulus which a subject detects 50 percent of the time. Weber's law suggests it is directly proportional to the original stimulus.

Practitioners of this area of business may use psychophysics to see if segments of consumers notice a difference when product attributes change. Strategies in this field may be "D2C" or "B2B" focused.

parts: Name this 3rd century B.C. philosopher whose namesake text contains the story of "Drumming on a Tub and Singing" and provides the most thorough exposition of an earlier man's doctrine of wu wei.

Herbert Giles used the Greek name for this process to describe Zhuangzi's dream of entering the body of a butterfly. In the Meno, Socrates explains recollection with the analogy of a tale in which this process is caused by Persephone.

The notion of de ("duh"), as treated in the Zhuangzi, is often translated into English as this concept. Plato and Aristotle put forth an ethics based on this concept, which is often contrasted with vice.

This person wrote the script of Capra's film Your Job in Germany, which depicts World War II as a racial conflict against the "eternal German". Richard Minear's book titled "[this person] goes to War" includes 200 of this person's World War II cartoons.
Name these programmable integrated circuits, which consist of a CPU, memory, and multiple I/O ports. Arduino packages the AVR variety of these devices onto single printed circuit boards.
Many Arduino ICs have an SCL line, which serves this purpose in the I²C ("EYE-two-SEE") protocol for communication. These devices' namesake "cycles", measured in hertz, rate the speed of a CPU.
This quantity is the speed at which serially-communicated data is transferred. The Arduino code "Serial.begin()" (serial-DOT-begin) sets this value when reading analog signals.
